title: 103_s1249
content: The Act may be cited as the "Tuberculosis Prevention and Control Amendments of 1993". Between 10,000,000 and 15,000,000 people in the United States have been infected with tuberculosis, with nearly 26,000 new cases reported annually and over 1,700 deaths each year. The number of reported cases has increased from 22,201 in 1985 to 26,673 in 1992, with drug-resistant strains costing more. In 1992, 27% of tuberculosis cases occurred in foreign-born persons, with drug-resistant strains costing over $150,000 to treat and resulting in a 40-60% mortality rate. Reported cases of drug-resistant tuberculosis were found in at least 36 states, the District of Columbia, and Puerto Rico. In 1992, 27% of tuberculosis cases occurred in foreign-born persons, with an estimated 8,000,000 new cases and 2,900,000 deaths worldwide each year. SEC. 3. PROGRAMS OF CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION. The amendment to the Public Health Service Act includes increased funding for prevention, control, and elimination services for fiscal years 1994-1997. Additionally, a new paragraph is added regarding State Tuberculosis Plan grant applications. The amendment to the Public Health Service Act includes increased funding for prevention, control, and elimination services for fiscal years 1994-1997. A new paragraph requires State grant applications for tuberculosis services to target high-risk populations or areas with high infection rates and collaborate with other relevant entities. The amendment to the Public Health Service Act includes increased funding for prevention, control, and elimination services for fiscal years 1994-1997. State grant applications for tuberculosis services must target high-risk populations and collaborate with relevant entities for directly observed therapy or other effective interventions. The amendment to the Public Health Service Act allows the Secretary to conduct or support research and training on tuberculosis surveillance, diagnostic methods, prevention, control, and treatment in support of grants. The Public Health Service Act authorizes funding for tuberculosis research and training on surveillance, diagnostics, prevention, control, and treatment. $26,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 1994, with additional funding for subsequent years. Technical amendment to the Public Health Service Act removes a sentence from Section 317(j)(2) regarding funding for tuberculosis research and training. SEC. 4. Research and research training regarding tuberculosis is added to the Public Health Service Act. Section 447 of the Public Health Service Act authorizes basic research and training on tuberculosis, while a conforming amendment is made to Section 446. Authorization of appropriations for this purpose is also included in Section 408(a). The Health Service Act is amended to authorize $46,000,000 for research on tuberculosis through the National Institute on Allergy and Infectious Diseases for fiscal year 1994, with additional funding for subsequent years. This authorization does not affect any other appropriations for the same purpose. SEC. 5. RESEARCH THROUGH THE FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION. A new section, SEC. 512A, is added to the Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act for tuberculosis drug and device research. The Commissioner of Food and Drugs will implement a tuberculosis drug and device research program, providing assistance for protocol development, reviewing medical devices for tuberculosis, and conducting research on drugs and devices. $5,000,000 is authorized annually for this program.
